class_notes:
This course provides an introduction to social psychology, an interdisciplinary field which systematically examines how the actual, imagined, or implied presence of other people influences a person's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. The focus of the course is on how groups ranging from friendship circles to ethnic groups affect the life of an individual and how the individual affects the group. The course examines the reciprocal relationship between individual-level and group-level phenomena and how inequalities emerging in interactions have consequences for larger groups and organizations. The course has three parts: (1) the self and identity, (2) cognition, perception, and emotions, and (3) group processes.


This class is meant primarily for non-seniors. The waitlist is opened only after these students are enrolled
course_description: Conditions and processes of group formation and change, and the effects of these on individual behavior and adaptation.
